title: Death In Paradise at risk of 'different disease every year' on set
text:
Kris Marshall was at risk from viruses on Death In Paradise (Picture: BBC)

The crew on Death In Paradise were struck down by a tropical disease ‘every year’, according to former star Kris Marshall.

Kris played DI Humphrey Goodman on the crime drama, filmed in Guadeloupe in the Caribbean, from 2014 to 2017.

Recalling his time on the show, he added that the role came with health risks – although the cast were lucky enough to dodge them.

On Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, presenter Adil Ray asked Kris what working in the exotic location was like: ‘You’ve got to be careful of not catching serious illnesses. That show is literally plagued by…whether it’s the Zika virus and chicken…what was it?’

Kris explained: ‘We had a different one every year actually. First one was dengue, the second year was the chikungunya, third one was Zika and I don’t know what the other one was – plague, locusts.’

Kris filmed the BBC show in the Caribbean (Picture: ITV)

Adil said: ‘I’ve heard stories of actors who go into the hotel, and they see people sort of walking along the walls trying to stay up because they’ve been hit by this virus.’

‘Mainly it hit the crew. The actors weren’t that badly affected,’ Kris explained.

‘Because you were in hotel rooms and they were in tents,’ Adil joked.

The actor added: ‘Maybe they were sleeping on the beach and we were in Sedan chairs.’

Meanwhile it’s all change on the BBC drama as current star Ardal O’Hanlon has quit his role after three years ‘to explore other opportunities’.

He will be replaced by actor Ralf Little as new character DI Neville Parker.

In a description for the next series, Neville Parker is ‘reluctantly dispatched to the fictional island of Saint Marie to investigate the suspicious death of a woman from his home city, Manchester’.

Good Morning Britain airs weekdays from 6am on ITV.
